* [[List of Prime Ministers of Guinea|Prime Minister]] and Interim [[List of Presidents of Guinea|President]] [[Louis Lansana Beavogui]] removed from offices. * Colonel [[Lansana Conté]] installed as new President. | status = | combatants_header = | combatant1 = {{flagicon|Guinea}} [[Government of Guinea]] * [[Democratic Party of Guinea – African Democratic Rally|Democratic Party of Guinea]] (PDG) | combatant2 = {{flagicon|Guinea}} [[Military Committee of National Restoration]] (CMNR) * [[Military of Guinea]] | combatant3 = | commander1 = [[Louis Lansana Beavogui]] | commander2 = [[Lansana Conté]] | commander3 = | units1 = | units2 = | units3 = | strength1 = | strength2 = | strength3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = No casualties reported. | notes = | campaignbox = }} The '''1984 Guinean coup d'état''' was the bloodless [[Military of Guinea|military]] [[coup d'état|coup]] that took place in [[Guinea]] on 3 April 1984, led by Colonel [[Lansana Conté]].{{web cite|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/04/world/guinea-s-military-assumes-control-seals-off-nation.html|title=GUINEA'S MILITARY ASSUMES CONTROL; SEALS OFF NATION|author=|date=4 April 1984|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=26 October 2018}} It led to the deposition of [[List of Prime Ministers of Guinea|Prime Minister]] [[Louis Lansana Beavogui]], who held the office since 1972, and assumed interim presidential powers on 26 March, when the long-time [[List of Presidents of Guinea|President]] [[Ahmed Sékou Touré]] died during an emergency heart operation at the [[Cleveland Clinic]] in the [[United States]].{{web cite|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/27/obituaries/ahmed-sekou-toure-guinean-president-62-dies-conakry-guinea-march-26-upi.html|title=AHMED SEKOU TOURE, GUINEAN PRESIDENT, 62, DIES|author=|date=27 March 1984|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=26 October 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/28/obituaries/ahmed-sekou-toure-a-radical-hero.html|title=Ahmed Sekou Toure, a Radical Hero|last=Pace|first=Eric|date=March 28, 1984|work=The New York Times|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} ==The coup== Colonel Conté announced the dissolution of the ruling [[Democratic Party of Guinea – African Democratic Rally|Democratic Party of Guinea]] (PDG), the [[National Assembly (Guinea)|National Assembly]] and all mass organizations, suspension of the [[Constitution of Guinea|Constitution]], creation of the [[Military Committee of National Restoration]] (CMNR) as the ruling [[Military junta|junta]], and ordered release of political prisoners held at [[Camp Boiro]] [[concentration camp]].{{web cite|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/12/world/in-post-coup-guinea-a-jail-is-thrown-open.html|title=IN POST-COUP GUINEA, A JAIL IS THROWN OPEN|author=|date=12 April 1984|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=26 October 2018}} Conté was named new President on 5 April.{{web cite|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/06/world/colonel-is-named-guinean-president.html|title=COLONEL IS NAMED GUINEAN PRESIDENT|author=|date=6 April 1984|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=26 October 2018}} ==Aftermath== Eventually, a power struggle developed between Conté and a fellow member of the CMNR, [[Diarra Traoré]] (who briefly served as Prime Minister in April–December 1984), with the latter being executed in the aftermath of a failed coup attempt in July 1985.{{web cite|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/07/06/world/coup-attempt-foiled-in-guinea-army-searches-for-rebel-leader.html|title=COUP ATTEMPT FOILED IN GUINEA; ARMY SEARCHES FOR REBEL LEADER|author=|date=6 July 1985|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=26 October 2018}}{{web cite|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/07/08/world/leader-of-guinea-uprising-to-be-shot-president-says.html|title=LEADER OF GUINEA UPRISING TO BE SHOT, PRESIDENT SAYS|author=|date=8 July 1985|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=26 October 2018}} Conté took advantage of the coup attempt to execute several of Ahmed Sekou Touré's close associates, including his half-brother [[Ismaël Touré]] (former chief prosecutor at Camp Boiro), [[Mamadi Keïta]], [[Siaka Touré]] (former commander of Camp Boiro), [[Moussa Diakité]],{{sfn|Lewin|2009|pp=27}} and [[Abdoulaye Touré]] (former [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Guinea)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]]).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kIiHwg3Y5u4C&pg=PA195|page=195|chapter=Toure, Al Jajj Abdoulaya|title=Historical dictionary of Guinea|author=Thomas O'Toole, Janice E. Baker|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=2005|ISBN=0-8108-4634-9}} Conté remained in power until his death on 22 December 2008,[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jFamnEzZhIYHzv_eUXSc1TxAMfkA "Guinea's long-time military leader Conte dies"], AFP, 23 December 2008.[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/12/23/africa/AF-Guinea-Obit-Conte.php "Guinea's dictator, Lansana Conte, dies"], Associated Press (''International Herald Tribune''), 23 December 2008. which was almost immediately followed by another [[2008 Guinean coup d'état|coup d'état]], led by Captain [[Moussa Dadis Camara]].[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jaQPxwTr7Ls-HVfZkk2xle0dPUhQD9589THO0 "Military-led group announces coup in Guinea"], Associated Press, 23 December 2008.[http://news.smh.com.au/world/death-of-guinea-dictator-prompts-coup-20081223-741k.html "Death of Guinea dictator prompts 'coup'"], AFP (''Sydney Morning Herald''), 23 December 2008. ==See also== *[[History of Guinea]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Guinea topics}} {{Years in Guinea}} {{African coups d'État}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1984 Guinean coup d'état}} [[Category:Military coups in Guinea]] [[Category:1984 in Guinea]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1984]] [[Category:1980s coups d'état and coup attempts]] [[Category:April 1984 events]]

{{other uses}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Alan Bond | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1938|4|22}} | birth_place = [[Hammersmith]], [[London]], [[England]], United Kingdom | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2015|6|5|1938|4|22}} | death_place = [[Murdoch, Western Australia]] | death_cause = Complications from [[heart surgery]] | nationality = Australian | other_names = "Bondy" | occupation = Businessman | known_for = Business magnate, yachting sponsor and corporate criminal | criminal_charge = Corporate fraud | criminal_penalty = Four years' imprisonment | spouse = {{marriage|Eileen Hughes|1955|1992|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|[[Diana Bliss]]|1995|2012|reason=died}} | children = Susanne, John, Craig, Jody | website = {{URL|http://beda.co.uk/bond1/}} | footnotes = }} '''Alan Bond''' (22 April 1938 – 5 June 2015) was an Australian businessman noted for his high-profile business dealings, including his central role in the [[WA Inc]] scandals of the 1980s, and what was at the time the biggest corporate collapse in Australian history; for his bankrolling the successful challenge for the [[1983 America's Cup]], the first time the [[New York Yacht Club]] had ever lost it in its 132-year history; and also for a criminal conviction that saw him serve four years in prison. The prestigious Alan Cup road hockey tournament is held at Bond University in his name. ==Career== Born in London and raised in Australia from the age of 12, Bond began his career as a [[signwriter]] and formed what became the Bond Corporation in 1959. He became a public hero in his adopted country after bankrolling challenges for the [[America's Cup]], which resulted in his selection in 1978 as [[Australian of the Year]]{{cite book|author=[[Wendy Lewis|Lewis, Wendy]]|title=Australians of the Year|publisher=Pier 9 Press|year=2010|isbn=978-1-74196-809-5}} (awarded jointly with [[Galarrwuy Yunupingu]]). His ''[[Australia II]]'' syndicate won the [[1983 America's Cup]], which had been held by the New York Yacht Club since 1851, thus breaking the longest winning streak in the history of sport. ==Conviction for fraud== In 1992, Bond was declared bankrupt with personal debts totalling A$1.8 billion. He was subsequently convicted of fraud and imprisoned after pleading guilty to using his controlling interest in Bell Resources to deceptively siphon off A$1.2 billion into the coffers of Bond Corporation. The funds were used to shore up the cash resources of the ailing Bond Corporation, which spectacularly collapsed, leaving Bell Resources in a precarious situation. ==Return to corporate activity== Following release, he became active in various mining investments, predominately in Africa, including Madagascar Oil PLC and Global Diamond Resources, of [[Lesotho]] and was included in [[BRW (magazine)|''Business Review Weekly'']]'s "Rich 200 List" in 2008. On 24 and 25 April 2017, the [[Nine Network]] aired a heavily fictionalised TV mini-series, [[House of Bond]], based on Bond's rise and fall. ==Early life== Alan Bond was born on 22 April 1938, the son of Frank and Kathleen Bond{{cite news|last1=Tovey|first1=Josephine|title=Obituary: Alan Bond, 1938-2015|url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/obituary-alan-bond-19382015-20150605-ghgnia.html|accessdate=20 April 2016|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=5 June 2015}} in the [[Hammersmith]] district of [[London]], England. In 1950, aged 12, he emigrated to Australia with his parents and his older sister Geraldine,{{cite web|title=Alan Bond, entrepreneur and businessman |url=http://www.beda.co.uk/bond2/ |work=beda.co.uk |accessdate=29 January 2012 |year=2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205021540/http://www.beda.co.uk/bond2/ |archivedate=5 February 2012 }} living in [[Fremantle]], near Perth. At age 14, he was charged with stealing and being unlawfully on premises. At age 18, he was arrested for being unlawfully on premises and reportedly admitted planning a robbery.{{cite news|last1=Barry|first1=Paul|title=Alan Bond dead: Paul Barry's account of a man who tricked Australia|url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/alan-bond-dead-paul-barrys-account-of-a-man-who-tricked-australia-20150604-ghgzxm|accessdate=20 April 2016|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=5 June 2015}} ==Business success== [[File:Hklippocenter.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[Lippo Centre (Hong Kong)|Lippo Centre]] in Admiralty, Hong Kong Island, 1988. Bought from Alan Bond.]] The [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]]-based Bond made his fortune initially in property development and at one time was one of Australia's most prominent businesspeople. In 1970 he bought three America's Cup challenge yachts from Sir [[Frank Packer]]. He later extended his business interests into other fields including [[brewing]] (he controlled Castlemaine [[Tooheys]] in Australia,{{cite news|url=https://www.brewsnews.com.au/2015/06/bondy-and-bernie-beer-in-the-80s/|work=Australian Brews News|title=Alan Bond and Bernie Powers: Beer in the ‘80s|date=5 June 2015|accessdate=9 June 2015|first=Matt|last=Kirkegaard}} leading the business to legal success in the landmark [[Australian constitutional law|constitutional law]] case of ''[[Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd v South Australia]]'',{{cite AustLII|HCA|1|1990|litigants=[[Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd v South Australia]] |parallelcite=(1990) 169 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 436 |date=7 February 1990 |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}}. and [[G. Heileman Brewing Company]] in [[La Crosse, Wisconsin]], USA{{cite news|url=http://lacrossetribune.com/news/local/former-heileman-s-owner-alan-bond-dies/article_5c811772-6554-5ab9-8d39-fb06de141121.html|title=Former Heileman's owner Alan Bond dies|work=La Crosse Tribune|date=6 June 2015|first=Jeff|last=Kish|accessdate=9 June 2015}}), [[gold mining]],{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-05/alan-bond-10-things-you-need-to-know/6520736|title=Alan Bond: 10 things you need to know about the controversial tycoon|date=4 June 2015|accessdate=9 June 2015|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]}} [[television]],{{cite news|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|title=Alan Bond: Australia's weak spot for the man behind the biggest heist in history |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-05/ian-verrender-on-alan-bond/6525132|first=Ian|last=Verrender|date=5 June 2015|accessdate=9 June 2015}} and [[Airship Industries|airships]].{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com.au/alan-bond-has-died-2015-6|agency=Business Insider|title=Fraudster and America's Cup legend Alan Bond dies|date=5 June 2015|accessdate=9 June 2015}} In 1987, Australia's first private university, [[Bond University]] was founded by Bond Corporation."[https://bond.edu.au/news/46724/bond-university-mourns-passing-mr-alan-bond Bond University mourns the passing of Mr Alan Bond]". [[Bond University]], 5 June 2015 He purchased [[QTQ-9]] [[Brisbane]] and settled an outstanding [[slander and libel|defamation]] dispute the station had with the [[Queensland]] premier, [[Joh Bjelke-Petersen]] by paying out [[Australian dollar|A$]]400,000. He said in a television interview several years later that he paid because "Sir Joh left no doubt that if we were going to continue to do business successfully in Queensland then he expected the matter to be resolved".{{cite book|title=Reviving the Fourth Estate: Democracy, Accountability and the Media|first=Julianne|last=Schultz|page=104|year=1998|publisher=Cambridge University Press}} In 1987, Bond purchased [[Vincent van Gogh]]'s renowned painting, ''[[Irises (painting)|Irises]],'' for $54 million—the highest price ever paid for a single painting. However, the purchase was funded by a substantial loan from the auctioneer, [[Sotheby's]], which Bond failed to repay. The transaction was criticised by art dealers as possibly a manipulated sale designed to artificially inflate values generally (which it seems to have done).Reif, Rita [https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/18/arts/a-27-million-loan-by-sotheby-s-helped-alan-bond-to-buy-irises.html A $27 Million Loan by Sotheby's Helped Alan Bond to Buy 'Irises'] New York Times, 18 October 1989 The painting was subsequently re-sold in 1990 to the [[Getty Center|J. Paul Getty Museum]] in [[Los Angeles]].[http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artObjectDetails?artobj=947&handle=li ''Irises'', image] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609143415/http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artObjectDetails?artobj=947&handle=li |date=9 June 2007 }} at the J. Paul Getty Museum Also in 1987, he built and developed the Bond Centre in [[Hong Kong]]. It was later bought by the [[Lippo Group]] of Indonesia and is now known as the [[Lippo Centre (Hong Kong)|Lippo Centre]].[https://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2012646468/ Bond Centre] at [[Library of Congress]] ===Purchasing the Nine Network=== In 1987, Bond paid $1 billion for the Australia-wide Channel Nine television network from [[Kerry Packer]]'s [[Publishing and Broadcasting Limited|PBL]]. In a 2003 interview with [[Andrew Denton]], Bond described the negotiations as follows:
"...when we first sat down, we said, 'We're either going to sell our stations to you for $400 million, or you're going to sell your stations to us.' And [Kerry Packer] said, 'Well, I don't really want to sell my stations.' And I said, 'Oh, is that right?' So, anyway, after much discussion, Kerry thumped the table and said, 'Listen, if you can pay me $1 billion, I'll sell them to you, otherwise bugger off'. ... [T]hen I rang the [[National Australia Bank]]. I said, 'Look, I'm in discussions here to buy these television stations. Kerry will sell to me, and what I want to do is put our stations together and then, with [[Sky Racing|Sky Channel]], I'm going to float it off as a separate entity and raise the capital to pay for it... [Packer] said $1 billion [was his asking price], but I think I'll get it for $800 million.' ... [The bank manager] duly rang back and said yes. I said, 'Thank God. I'll go and have some further negotiations with Kerry,' which I did. And true to his word, he never budged one penny off it. So I settled the deal with $800 million and a $200 million note. So he put his own $200 million in. So I had $1 billion. And we put our other two stations up as collateral, which were worth probably $400 million."[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/enoughrope/transcripts/s981486.htm Alan Bond interview transcript] from [[Enough Rope]], ABC TV interview with Andrew Denton, 3 November 2003
In fact, the agreed price was $1.05 billion. Packer took $800 million in cash and $250 million in subordinated debt in Bond Media. Once Bond went bankrupt, Packer was able to turn the debt into a 37% equity in Bond Media, which now included Channel 9 in Brisbane, and was worth about $500 million. It was valued at $1 billion, but had $500 million in debt on the books. Still, Packer was quoted as saying "You only get one Alan Bond in your lifetime, and I've had mine". ===Bankruptcy=== In 1992, Bond was declared bankrupt after failing to repay a $194 million personal guarantee on a loan for a [[nickel]] mining project. His debts reportedly totalled $1.8 billion at the time.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/15/business/alan-bond-is-declared-bankrupt-in-australia.html|title=Alan Bond Is Declared Bankrupt in Australia|date=15 April 1992|accessdate=9 June 2015|work=The New York Times}} In 1995, his family bought him out of bankruptcy, with creditors accepting a payment of A$12 million, a little over half a cent per dollar.{{cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/people/alan-bond-dies-van-gogh-305661|title=Australian Tycoon Alan Bond, Who Bought Vincent van Gogh's Irises for Record $54 Million in 1987, Is Dead at 77|agency=ArtNet News|first=Amah-Rose|last=Abrams|date=8 June 2015|accessdate=9 June 2015}} In 1997, Bond was sentenced to seven years in prison after pleading guilty to using his controlling interest in Bell Resources to deceptively siphon off A$1.2 billion into the coffers of Bond Corporation. The funds were used to shore up the cash resources of the ailing Bond Corporation, which spectacularly collapsed, leaving Bell Resources in a precarious situation.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2000/03/bond-m11.html|title=Australian businessman Alan Bond walks free from jail|first=Mike|last=Head|agency=World Socialist Web Site|date=11 March 2000|accessdate=9 June 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.afr.com/news/alan-bond-dead-bond-corps-demise-left-bad-taste-in-the-west-20150605-ghhjb1|title=Alan Bond dead: Bond Corp's demise left bad taste in the West|date=5 June 2015|accessdate=9 June 2015|work=Financial Review|first=Julie-anne|last=Sprague}} At this time, Bond was stripped of his 1984 honour as an [[Order of Australia|Officer of the Order of Australia]].Mickelburough, Peter "[http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/social-leaders-stripped-of-honours-after-falling-from-grace/story-fni0fit3-1226658920443 Social leaders stripped of honours after falling from grace]", ''[[Herald Sun]]'', 6 June 2013. Retrieved 20 March 2014 He was released from [[Karnet Prison Farm]] in 2000, having served four years in various West Australian prisons.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/671477.stm|work=BBC News|title=Alan Bond released from prison|date=9 March 2000|accessdate=23 April 2010}} ===Return to investment activities=== In 2003, Bond was inducted into the [[America's Cup Hall of Fame]].{{cite news|url=http://www.sail-world.com/Alan-Bond---America-s-Cup-Hero-remembered-by-Mad-Dog-and-Chink/135096|title=Alan Bond—America's Cup Hero remembered by Longley and Simmer|first=Richard|last=Gladwell|agency=Sail World|date=5 June 2015|accessdate=9 June 2015}} Since 2003, Bond had worked closely with his son Craig and longtime business partner Robert Quinn through Strategic Investments Ltd.Mottram, Linda; Daniel, Zoe [http://www.abc.net.au/am/stories/s508667.htm Bond's latest venture in liquidation][[AM (ABC Radio)|ABC Radio AM]] report, 20 March 2002Reece, Damian & Mary Fagan, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/4465580/Bond-on-comeback-trail.html Bond on comeback trail] The Telegraph (UK), 17 September 2000. Interests related to the Bond family also control [[Global Diamond Resources]] plc (formerly Lesotho Diamond Corporation) which is developing the Kao diamond pipe in the [[Lesotho|Kingdom of Lesotho]]. In 2007, the [[Federal Court of Australia|Federal Court]] rejected an attempt by Bond to sue freelance journalist [[Paul Barry]] over an article Barry wrote about his dealings in Africa with the Lesotho Diamond Company.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/09/21/2040263.htm Court dismisses case against journalist Paul Barry] [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]], 22 September 2007 Bond had claimed that the article had several false statements. In 2008 Bond appealed but this, too, was rejected by the same court which found Mr Bond's claims had no reasonable prospects of success.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/06/23/2282706.htm Bond loses Federal Court appeal], [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]], 23 June 2008 Bond was involved in a long-running defamation case against ''[[The West Australian]]'' newspaper and journalists Mark Drummond and Sean Cowan over a series of articles published in December 2005, in which it was alleged that Bond's friend and business partner Robert Leslie Nelson was moving to hide Bond's involvement in Lesotho Diamond Corporation, Madagascar Oil and a gold company.{{cite AustLII|WASC|121|2008|litigants=Bond v West Australian Newspapers Ltd |parallelcite= |date=25 June 2008 |courtname=[[Supreme Court of Western Australia|Supreme Court]] (WA)}}. During that case, Bond tried to have the journalists convicted of contempt of court after some electronic documents disappeared.Gosch, Elizabeth (27 March 2008). [http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/bond-seeks-newspaper-files/story-e6frg12c-1111115909348 "The West Australian newspaper 'erased documents'"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, PerthNow.com, 27 March 2008; retrieved 5 June 2015. In 2008, Bond made a return to the ''[[Business Review Weekly]]''{{'}}s "Rich 200 List", in 157th spot, with an estimated wealth of $265 million—thanks primarily to his stakes in Madagascar Oil and Global Diamond Resources.{{cite news|title=Rich surprise: Alan Bond bounces back|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=28 May 2008|url=http://business.smh.com.au/rich-surprise-alan-bond-bounces-back-20080528-2ixw.html|accessdate=28 May 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704093836/http://business.smh.com.au/rich-surprise-alan-bond-bounces-back-20080528-2ixw.html|archivedate=4 July 2008|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} ==Family== In 1955, Bond married Eileen Hughes, a member of a prominent [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] family in [[Fremantle]]—her cousin is car dealer [[John Hughes (motor dealer)|John Hughes]]. She and Bond were both 17 and she was pregnant at the time. Bond, who had been raised [[Protestantism|Protestant]], converted to Catholicism for the marriage. The couple had four children: John, Craig, Susanne and Jody. Bond and Eileen divorced in 1992.{{cite web|last=Wilson|first=Caroline|title=Why Alan Bond Split With Eileen|url=http://www.divorcesolicitors.com.au/divorce-solicitors-articles/1992/4/11/why-alan-bond-split-with-eileen/|work=The Sun Herald|accessdate=29 January 2012|date=11 April 1992}} Susanne, an equestrian showjumper who had been a member of the Australian showjumping team for seven years, died in 2000 from a suspected accidental overdose of prescription medication.{{cite web|last=Lowth|first=Adrienne|title=Coronial inquiry launched into the death of Alan Bond's daughter|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/stories/s149401.htm|publisher=abc.net.au|accessdate=29 January 2012|date=7 July 2000}} In 1995, Bond married [[Diana Bliss]], a public relations consultant and theatre producer.{{cite news|title=People in the News|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uHsiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OK0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3103,3927852&dq=alan-bond|accessdate=29 January 2012|newspaper=The Argus-Press|date=16 April 1995}} On 28 January 2012, Bliss was found dead in the couple's swimming pool. Police said the circumstances of her death were not suspicious{{cite web|title=Police confirm Alan Bond's wife dead|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-01-29/police-confirm-alan-bond27s-wife-dead/3798952|work=abc.net.au|accessdate=29 January 2012}} and concluded that Bliss, a longtime sufferer of [[major depressive disorder|depression]], had committed suicide.{{cite web|title=Diana Bliss leaves a last sad farewell note to Alan Bond|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/national/diana-bliss-last-sad-farewell-to-alan-bond/story-e6frea8c-1226257946907|work=news.com.au|accessdate=31 January 2012}} ==Illness and death== On 2 June 2015, Bond underwent open-heart surgery at a private hospital in Perth to replace and repair his [[heart valve]]s. Following complications, he was transferred to [[Fiona Stanley Hospital]] in Perth{{cite news|url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/alan-bond-dead-all-efforts-were-made-says-fiona-stanley-hospital-20150605-ghhz5a.html|title=Alan Bond dead: 'All efforts were made', says Fiona Stanley Hospital|publisher= Fairfax Media|work=WA Today|author=Leanne Nicholson|date=5 June 2015|accessdate=13 June 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/alan-bond-dead-larger-than-life-businessman-loses-fight-after-heart-surgery/story-fnhocxo3-1227384472700|title=Alan Bond dead: Larger-than-life businessman loses fight after heart surgery|author=Kate Campbell|publisher=The Sunday Times|work=PerthNow|date=5 June 2015|accessdate=13 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150607235906/http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/alan-bond-dead-larger-than-life-businessman-loses-fight-after-heart-surgery/story-fnhocxo3-1227384472700|archivedate=7 June 2015|df=dmy-all}} and placed on life support in an [[induced coma]];{{cite news| title=Alan Bond continues to fight for life in Perth hospital after heart surgery complications |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-04/alan-bond-continues-to-fight-for-life-in-perth-hospital/6520384 |accessdate=4 June 2015 |work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=4 June 2015}} he did not regain consciousness, and died on the morning of 5 June 2015."[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-05/alan-bond-dies-in-perth-after-heart-surgery-complications/6520630 Alan Bond dies in Perth hospital after heart surgery complications]" (5 June 2015), [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]. Retrieved 5 June 2015. == In popular culture == The Australian TV miniseries ''[[House of Bond]]'' (2017) is based on Bond's life and in it he is portrayed by [[Ben Mingay]]. The [[Crowded House]] song "Whispers and Moans" from the album [[Woodface]] makes a reference to "Alan's sound investments" towards the end of the song, an ironic reference to Alan Bond's financial conduct https://www.frenzforum.com/topic/whispers-and-moans-puzzle ==References== {{reflist|30em}} Nichola Schulz, Tourists: 4 | launch = 2021 (conceptual) | carrier_rocket = TBD | launch_pad = | reentry = | status = Concept | mass = | length = {{convert|13.3|m|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|4.3|m|abbr=on}} | height = | diameter = | volume = {{convert|160|m3|abbr=on}} | pressure = | perigee = | apogee = | inclination = | altitude = {{convert|320|km|abbr=on}} | speed = | period = 90 min | orbits_day = | in_orbit = | occupied = | orbits = | distance = | as_of = | stats_ref = | configuration_image = | configuration_landscape= | configuration_size = | configuration_alt = | configuration_caption = }} The '''Aurora Space Station''' is a technology concept for a private commercial [[space station]] in low Earth orbit that was announced on 5 March 2018 by [[Orion Span]], a startup aerospace company in California, USA. The concept envisions a capacity of six people: two crew and four tourists. [https://www.space.com/40207-space-hotel-launch-2021-aurora-station.html Luxury Space Hotel to Launch in 2021]. Mike Wall, ''Space''. 6 April 2018.[https://www.cnn.com/travel/article/aurora-station-luxury-space-hotel/index.html First luxury hotel in space announced]. Maureen O'Hare, ''CNN News''. 5 April 2018. No launch contract has been signed for deployment of the modules nor crewed vehicles,[http://spacenews.com/startup-announces-plans-for-low-cost-commercial-space-station/ Startup announces plans for low-cost commercial space station]. Jeff Foust, ''Space News''. 5 April 2018. and its construction has not started, but its representatives claim it will be launched in 2021. ==Overview== Frank Bunger, the founder and CEO of Orion Span, stated that the Aurora Station would offer to [[space tourist]]s a 12-day stay for US$9.5 million. He said that the design concept is such that the station would not require extravehicular activities (spacewalks) for assembly and operation. Orion Span plans to design, test and build the station in Houston, Texas. The company has yet to sign a launch contract, but stated that this commercial station would be deployed in [[low Earth orbit]] in 2021, and start to receive passengers in 2022. Bunger said that travelers will be required to complete a three-month training program before launch. Guests would be able to free-float, look out windows, practice [[hydroponics]], and play in a '[[Holodeck|hologram deck]]'.[https://www.nbcnews.com/mach/science/luxury-space-hotel-could-be-running-four-years-ncna863366 This luxury space hotel could be up and running in four years]. ''NBC News''. 5 April 2018. ==See also== *[[MirCorp]] *[[NewSpace]] *[[Space tourism]] *[[Bigelow Commercial Space Station]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.orionspan.com/ Orion Span] home web site *[https://universetoday.ru/2018/04/20/%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F-%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0-%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%82-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8B%D0%BC-%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5/ Станция Аврора станет первым космическим отелем класса люкс.] {{Space stations}} {{Space tourism}} [[Category:Proposed space stations]] [[Category:2021 in spaceflight]] [[Category:Space tourism]] [[Category:Private spaceflight companies]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox music festival | name = Bilbao BBK Live | image = [[File:Bilbao BBK Live-logo.jpg|250px|border]] | caption = Poster for 2012 edition of poster | location = Kobetamendi
[[Bilbao]], [[Spain]] | years_active = 2006-Present | founders = [[Basque Government]]
Last Tour International | dates = 12 – 14 July | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[pop music|pop]], [[alternative rock]], [[hard rock]], [[indie music|indie]], [[electronic music|electronic]] | website = {{URL|http://www.bilbaobbklive.com|Festival Website}} | organizer = Last Tour Concerts }} '''Bilbao BBK Live''' is a rock and pop [[music festival]] that takes place annually in the city of [[Bilbao]], [[Spain]]. Since its beginnings, the festival is held in its entirety on a special complex built specifically for the event on the slopes of [[mount Cobetas]], located southwest from the city. The first edition was organized by [[Basque people|Basque]] musical promoter Last Tour International and sponsored by the [[Bilbao City Hall]] in the year 2006 under the name ''Bilbao Live Festival''. Since the following year, the festival has been sponsored by local savings bank [[Bilbao Bizkaia Kutxa]], who gave it its current name. The festival is the first of its kind and size to happen in the region. In the 2011 edition, the festival exceeded 100,000 visitors for the first time, doubling the 2006 attendance.{{cite news |title= Kobetas conquista su cima|first= Josu|last= Olarte|url= http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/v/20110711/cultura/kobetas-conquista-cima-20110711.html|newspaper= [[El Correo]]|date= 11 July 2011|accessdate=21 March 2012}} The 2012 event was reported to left an economical impact estimated in over 17.5 million [[euro]]s in the city.{{cite news |title=El BBK Live cosecha 17,5 millones de euros, 1,3 más que en su edición de 2011|url= http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2012/07/18/paisvasco/1342606532.html|newspaper= [[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date= 18 July 2012|accessdate=18 July 2012}} The festival was nominated for "Best Foreign Festival" at the UK Festival Awards in 2010 and 2011,{{cite news |url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2011/09/19/paisvasco/1316461165.html |title=El BBK Live 2011, nominado en los UK Festival Awards a Mejor Festival Extranjero |newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] |date=19 September 2011 |accessdate=22 April 2012}} and for "Best Medium-Sized European Festival" at the [[European Festivals Awards]] three consecutive times in 2009-2011.{{cite news |url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2011/11/04/paisvasco/1320422460.html |title=Bilbao BBK Live, nominado por tercer año seguido a los European Festival Awards |newspaper=El Mundo |date=4 November 2011 |accessdate=22 April 2012}} == History == === Organization and first edition === After an unsuccessful attempt to establish a [[Circuito Urbano Bilbao|street circuit]] in the city for the [[Formula Renault 3.5]] in July 2005, the city Government decided to fill in the summer events calendar with an open-air music festival.{{cite news |title= El primer gran festival de rock y pop de Bilbao presenta en julio a 25 grupos en el monte Cobetas |author= José Mari Reviriego |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/pg060201/prensa/noticias/Vizcaya/200602/01/VIZ-VIZ-079.html |newspaper= [[El Correo]]|date= 1 February 2006 |accessdate= 22 March 2012}} In early 2006, it approached local musical promoter Last Tour International, responsible for the organization of the [[Azkena Rock Festival]], celebrated in nearby [[Vitoria-Gasteiz]] since 2002. The newborn festival received the name of ''Bilbao Live Festival'', and had a budget of 4.2 million [[euro]]s.{{cite news |title=Guns N' Roses y Placebo encabezarán un Bilbao Live que apuesta por la electrónica |url=http://elpais.com/diario/2006/05/16/paisvasco/1147808415_850215.html |newspaper=[[El País]] |date=16 May 2006 |accessdate=22 March 2012}} The newly developed area in mount Cobetas was chosen as the location, which included two main stages for the rock acts, two [[electronic music]] tents, one [[pop music]] tent, and several bars and shops. Over 40 national and international bands participated in the first edition, celebrated during three days between 13–15 July 2006. The headliners included [[United States|American]] [[hard rock]] band [[Guns N' Roses]], [[United Kingdom|British]] bands [[Placebo (band)|Placebo]] and [[Pretenders (band)|Pretenders]], and [[Argentinian]]s [[Andrés Calamaro]] and [[Ariel Roth]], former members of rock band [[Los Rodríguez]].{{cite news |title=Guns'n'Roses, Placebo y Pretenders, figuras destacadas del primer Bilbao Live Festival |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/pg060515/actualidad/cultura/200605/15/ECD_livefestivalbilbao.html |newspaper=El Correo |date=15 May 2006 | accessdate=22 March 2012}}{{cite news |title=Más de 51.000 personas se dieron cita en la primera edición del Bilbao Live Festival |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/pg060717/actualidad/vizcaya/200607/17/ECD_bilbao-live.html |newspaper=El Correo |date=17 July 2006 |accessdate=22 March 2012}} Over 51,000 people attended this first edition, and was considered a "success". LTI representative, Alfonso Santiago praised the organization and the music acts,{{cite news |title=No hubo un concierto malo |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/pg060718/prensa/noticias/Vizcaya/200607/18/VIZ-SUBARTICLE-066.html |newspaper=El Correo |date=18 July 2006 |accessdate=22 March 2012}} and defined the festival as a "good starting point". The festival was well received by critics, the authorities, and the general public, and a second edition for the next year was confirmed on 28 July 2006, with the possibility of making it a "permanent musical event" of the city's cultural offer.{{cite news |title=El Bilbao Live Festival volverá a celebrarse en 2007 |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/pg060728/actualidad/sociedad/200607/28/ECD_bilbao_live.html |newspaper=El Correo |date=28 July 2006 |accessdate=22 March 2012}}{{cite news |title=El Ayuntamiento de Bilbao apuesta por repetir el festival de Cobetas |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/pg060718/prensa/noticias/Vizcaya/200607/18/VIZ-VIZ-065.html |author=José Mari Reviriego |newspaper=El Correo |date=18 July 2006 |accessdate=22 March 2012}} === BBK sponsorship and consolidation === [[File:Bilbao - BBK 1 (Gran Via).jpg|thumb|200px|BBK, the main sponsor since 2007.]] In early 2007, local savings bank [[Bilbao Bizkaia Kutxa]] decided to become an official sponsor for the festival, as part of the actions for its 100th anniversary celebration campaign. As a result, the festival's name was changed to ''Bilbao BBK Live''.{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/prensa/20070224/cultura_viz/festival-bilbao-live-adelanta_20070224.html |title=El festival Bilbao Live se adelanta a junio y tendrá en exclusiva a Red Hot Chili Peppers| newspaper=El Correo |date=24 February 2007 |author=G. Carrera |accessdate=22 March 2012}} Unlike other sponsorship renamings, where the sponsor's name is usually dropped in an informal context, this festival is commonly referred to as "the BBK Live" or simply "the BBK". The second edition enjoyed a "significant budget rise", and the area designated for the stages and camping was also increased from 70,000 to 110,000 m².{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20070223/vizcaya/chili-pepers-encabeza-cartel_200702231306.html |title=Red Hot Chili Pepers encabeza el cartel del 'Bilbao Live Festival' que se adelanta a junio |date=23 February 2007 |newspaper=El Correo |accessdate=22 March 2012}} The 2007 edition was also the first (and currently only) to be celebrated in June, a decision took based on the "European summer festival calendar". An extra date was also added, spanning two weekends, 21-22 and 28–29 June. American bands [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], [[Metallica]], [[Incubus (band)|Incubus]], [[New York Dolls]], [[My Chemical Romance]], and British [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[Iron Maiden]] were among the international headliners for this edition, meanwhile local rock band [[Fito & Fitipaldis]] stood out among [[Spanish rock|Spanish acts]], and received the largest audience of the event.{{cite news |url=http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/237491/l/ |title=Cerrado el cartel del Bilbao BBK Live con ocho nuevas incorporaciones |newspaper=[[20 Minutos]] |author=D. Cabezas |date=23 May 2007 |accessdate=22 March 2012}} Over 95,000 people attended the event, and produced an economical impact estimated in 13 million euros.{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20080629/cultura/monte-20080629.html |title=Monte Pop |newspaper=El Correo |first=Josu|last=Olarte |date= |accessdate=18 April 2012}} [[File:Bilbao BBK Live 08.jpg|thumb|left|The main stage for the 2008 edition.]] [[File:Dusty Hill ZZ Top BBK Live 2008 I.jpg|thumb|[[Dusty Hill]] in the 2008 edition.]] For the 2008 edition, the festival moved back to its original dates in the first weekend of July and a three-day programme. This edition was headlined by American acts [[R.E.M. (band)|R.E.M.]], [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[ZZ Top]], and British bands [[The Police]], [[The Prodigy]], and [[Madness (band)|Madness]].{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20080411/cultura/bilbao-live-paso-ficha-20080411.html |title=El Bilbao BBK Live da 'un paso más' y ficha a Madness |newspaper=El Correo |first=Isabel|last=Ibáñez |date=11 April 2008 |accessdate=18 April 2012}} This year saw the introduction of a new festival in the city; [[Kobetasonik]] was focused in [[heavy metal music]], was headlined by [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]] and [[Judas Priest]], and was held two weeks before BBK Live in the same venue at mount Cobetas. Bilbao BBK Live 08 was attended by a little less than 80,000 people, well below the expected 95,000. Rain and difficult access to the site, available only through shuttle buses provided by a private party instead of the city's public buses as in past editions, were seen as factors for the decrease in attendance.{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20080708/opinion/exito-total-20080708.html |title=Éxito total |newspaper=El Correo |author= |date=8 July 2008 |accessdate=18 April 2012}} However, the edition was still considered a success, and despite a project of moving the festival to a new location at an abandoned [[amusement park]] in [[mount Artxanda]],{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20080716/mas-actualidad/sociedad/propone-trasladar-bilbao-live-200807161443.html |title=El PP propone trasladar el Bilbao Live al antiguo parque de atracciones de Artxanda |newspaper=El Correo |first=María|last=Rego |date=16 July 2008 |accessdate=18 April 2012}} the organization decided to stick to Cobetas, and promised improvements in the area and services for 2009.{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20080709/cultura/recinto-kobetamendi-sera-mejorado-20080709.html |title=El recinto de Kobetamendi será mejorado para las futuras ediciones del Bilbao BBK Live |newspaper=El Correo |first=Isabel|last=Ibáñez |date= |accessdate=18 April 2012}} The fourth edition, held between 9–11 July 2009 suffered greatly from the [[2008–2012 Spanish financial crisis|financial crisis]] that struck Spain in that period. As a result, the line-up was considerately "less commercial", as defined by the organization. Headliners included [[Depeche Mode]], [[Jane's Addiction]], [[Kaiser Chiefs]], [[Editors (band)|Editors]], and second-timers [[Placebo (band)|Placebo]], among others.{{cite web |url=http://www.efestivals.co.uk/festivals/bilbaobbk/2009/ |title=Bilbao BBK Live '09 |publisher=efestivals.co.uk |date=16 June 2009 |accessdate=19 April 2012}} The festival received over 52,600 visitors, a "foreseen decrease",{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20090708/cultura/mejor-cartel-posible-tiempos-20090708.html |title="El mejor cartel posible" en tiempos de crisis |date=8 July 2009 |accessdate=19 April 2012 |first=Isabel|last=Ibáñez |newspaper=El Correo}} and although considered a "step back", the continuity of the festival was confirmed.{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20090713/mas-actualidad/cultura/asistencia-personas-confirma-continuidad-200907131547.html |title=La asistencia de más de 52.000 personas confirma la continuidad del BBK Live |newspaper=El Correo |date=13 July 2009 |accessdate=19 April 2012}} This edition saw an increase of foreign visitors, a 5-point increase from the past edition, totaling 14,6%. Foreign attendees came principally from [[France]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. This was mainly due to a special offer aimed to anyone with a postal address outside of Spain, with a three-day ticket for £40, one third of the standard price.{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20090714/cultura/live-vuelve-internacional-20090714.html |title=El BBK se vuelve más internacional |date=14 July 2009 |accessdate=19 April 2012 |newspaper=El Correo |author=Jon Fernández}}{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20090514/cultura/bilbao-live-oferta-bonos-20090514.html |title=El Bilbao Live oferta bonos a 53 euros en Reino Unido |newspaper=El Correo |date=14 May 2009 |first=Isabel|last=Ibáñez |accessdate=19 April 2012}} == Lineups by year == === 2006 === Number of visitors: 51.000 {| class="wikitable" | colspan="4" align="center" | '''Stages''' |- !July 13 !July 14 !July 15 |- |valign="top" align="center" width=200| [[Ben Harper|Ben Harper and the Innocent Criminals]]

Daniel Baughman |} == Impact == The 2012 edition is said to have left an economical impact estimated in over 17.5 million euros, taking into account the expenditures of the general public, organization, sponsors, and artists during the three days of the festival. This indicates an increase of 1.3 million when compared to the previous edition. During festival days, the city's hotels had an occupancy rate of 95%.{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/v/20110705/vizcaya/hoteles-bilbao-recibiran-live-20110705.html |title=Los hoteles de Bilbao recibirán el BBK Live con un 95% de ocupación |date=5 July 2011 |accessdate=22 April 2012 |newspaper=El Correo}} LTI spokesman, Alfonso Santiago, stated that Bilbao has established itself as the third Spanish concert capital, behind [[Madrid]] and [[Barcelona]].{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/v/20110427/cultura/importante-haya-promotores-apuesten-20110427.html |title=Es importante que haya promotores que apuesten por la ciudad y que las instituciones apoyen sus iniciativas |date=27 April 2011 |first=Óscar|last=Cubillo |newspaper=El Correo |accessdate=22 April 2012}} Along with ''[[Bilbao#Festival|Aste Nagusia]]'', the local [[Fiesta patronal|patronage festival]] held each August, BBK Live is often cited as an important component of the city's cultural offer, and responsible for the 200,000 tourists that Bilbao receives each summer.{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/v/20110210/vizcaya/bilbao-encarama-turistas-20110210.html |title=Bilbao se encarama a los 700.000 turistas |newspaper=El Correo |date=11 February 2011 |first= Jorge|last= Barbó |accessdate=22 April 2012}} Many travel agencies offer special packages with transportation, accommodation and festival tickets.{{cite news |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/v/20110708/cultura/muchas-agencias-viajes-ofrecen-20110708.html |title=Muchas agencias de viajes ya ofrecen paquetes con el festival incluido |newspaper=El Correo |date=8 July 2011 |author=M. Martínez |accessdate=22 April 2012}} == Venue == [[File:BBK Live Cobetas.jpg|thumb|The food and drink stands during the 2008 edition.]] Bilbao BBK Live is an open-air festival that takes place at Kobetamendi, located in [[Mount Cobetas]], southeast from the city centre. With {{convert|18.5|ha|acre|abbr=on}}, it is Bilbao's largest park. The venue is built each year around a 110,000 m² area and features three main stages, a DJs Tent, VIP zone, backstage facilities, food and drinks markets, and two camping areas, that total {{convert|30,000|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} and have a total capacity of 15,000 people. == Bilbao BBK Live Bereziak == Since 2011, the organization decided to arrange a series of spin-off concerts to be held at ''Sala BBK'', a small venue located at the centre of the city, on the [[Gran Vía de Don Diego López de Haro|Gran Vía]], the city's main street. Under the name Bilbao BBK Live Bereziak ([[Basque language|Basque]]: Bilbao BBK Live Specials), it consists of a cycle of small profile concerts with a very limited capacity, distributed along the year. Among the artists that participated in this specials are: [[Lambchop (band)|Lambchop]], [[M. Ward]], and [[Tortoise (band)|Tortoise]].{{cite web |url=http://www.eitb.com/es/cultura/bilbao-bbk-live/detalle/794622/bilbao-bbk-live-bereziak-lambchop-corizonas-aforo-limitado/ |title=Bilbao BBK Live Bereziak: Lambchop y Corizonas en aforo limitado |publisher=[[EITB]] |date=9 February 2012 |accessdate=22 April 2012}}[http://www.salabbk.es/archives/643 "Sin asomo de nostalgia"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330205046/http://www.salabbk.es/archives/643 |date=30 March 2012 }}. Sala [http://todoindie.com/bbk-live/ BBK]. The '''Boroondara Eisteddfod''' is a music competition held annually in the [[Boroondara City Council|City of Boroondara]], [[Melbourne, Australia|Melbourne]], [[Australia]].
== History == The first Eisteddfod was held in 1991 as the Camberwell Eisteddfod, under the auspices of the then-[[City of Camberwell]]. It was formed to provide a musical competition for the area, following the closure of the Hartwell Eisteddfod.<ref name="sscminutes">{{cite web|title=Minutes of the Boroondara Services Special Committee 18 July 2011|url=https://www.boroondara.vic.gov.au/-/media/Files/Your%20Council/Meetings%20and%20Agendas/Council/2011%20Special%20Services%20Committee/2011%2007%2018%20SSC%20minutes.pdf|publisher=City of Boroondara|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="2016council">{{cite web|title=Boroondara Council Meeting Agenda 26 April 2016|url=https://www.boroondara.vic.gov.au/-/media/Files/Your%20Council/Meetings%20and%20Agendas/Council/20160426/Report5%20Boroondara%20Eisteddfod|publisher=City of Boroondara|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> Venues included the City of Camberwell Ballroom and Balwyn Community Centre.<ref>{{cite news|title=Live Theatre Directory|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/120514851/|accessdate=8 June 2016|publisher=The Age|date=25 June 1993}}</ref>
In the events surrounding the sacking of the Camberwell Council in 1993, the [[Government of Victoria|Victorian Government's]] investigation into the council examined the circumstances under which the event was established. It found that the expenditure on the 1992 Eisteddfod "likely...was illegal" due to its failure to be properly authorised.<ref>{{cite web|title=Investigation into Camberwell Council|url=http://www.parliament.vic.gov.au/papers/govpub/VPARL1992-94No33.pdf|website=Parliament of Victoria|publisher=Office of Local Government|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> Nevertheless, the Eisteddfod continued.
Following council amalgamations in 1994, Camberwell became part of the new City of Boroondara and the Eisteddfod was renamed to account for this change.<ref name="sscminutes"></ref>
=== Hawthorn Town Hall redevelopment === During the redevelopment of the [[Hawthorn Town Hall]] into a regional arts centre, the Eisteddfod's main venues became unavailable. This necessitated moving events to other venues across Boroondara, including the [[Methodist Ladies' College, Melbourne|Methodist Ladies' College]], [[Camberwell Town Hall]] and [[Kew Court House]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Come along to the Eisteddfod|url=https://bulletin.boroondara.vic.gov.au/come-along-to-the-eisteddfod/|publisher=City of Boroondara|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> The Eisteddfod moved back to the newly-refurbished Hawthorn Arts Centre in 2015.

{{about|the film|other uses|Cannibal Holocaust (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = Cannibal Holocaust | image = Cannibal Holocaust movie.jpg | alt = | caption = Italian [[film poster]] | director = [[Ruggero Deodato]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Franco Di Nunzio * Franco Palaggi }} | writer = [[Gianfranco Clerici]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Robert Kerman]] * [[Carl Gabriel Yorke]] * [[Francesca Ciardi]] * [[Luca Barbareschi]] * [[Perry Pirkanen]] }} | music = [[Riz Ortolani]] | cinematography = Sergio D'Offizi | editing = Vincenzo Tomassi | studio = F.D. Cinematografica | distributor = [[United Artists|United Artists Europa]] | released = {{Film date|df=y|1980|02|07}} | runtime = 96 minutes | country = Italy | language = English | budget = [[United States dollar|US$]]100,000<ref name="In the Jungle"/> | gross = $2 million {{small|(United States)}}<ref>{{citeweb |url= https://medium.com/@giliandelacruz01/what-are-the-top-grossing-cannibal-movies-of-all-time-120bd8d696f8 |title=What are the top grossing cannibal movies of all time? |website=[[Medium (website)|Medium]] |author= Cruz, Dela, Gillian |date= 8 February 2017 |accessdate= 10 July 2018}}</ref><ref group=Note>This number represents available information on the film's initial United States theatrical run only.</ref> }} '''''Cannibal Holocaust''''' is a 1980 Italian [[cannibal film|cannibal]] [[horror film]] directed by [[Ruggero Deodato]] and written by [[Gianfranco Clerici]]. It stars [[Robert Kerman]] as Harold Monroe, an anthropologist from [[New York University]] who leads a rescue team into the [[Amazon rainforest]] to locate a crew of filmmakers. Played by [[Carl Gabriel Yorke]], [[Francesca Ciardi]], [[Perry Pirkanen]], and [[Luca Barbareschi]], the crew had gone missing while filming a documentary on local cannibal tribes. When the rescue team is only able to recover the crew's lost cans of film, an American television station wishes to broadcast the footage as a sensationalized television special. Upon viewing the reels, Monroe is appalled by the team's actions and objects to the station's intent to air the documentary.
Influenced by the documentaries of [[Mondo film|Mondo]] director [[Gualtiero Jacopetti]],<ref name="In the Jungle"/><ref name="Ortolani" /> ''Cannibal Holocaust'' was inspired by Italian media coverage of [[Red Brigade]] terrorism. The coverage included news reports that Deodato believed to be staged, an idea which became an integral aspect of the film's story.<ref name="Interview 2"/> Approximately half of the film consists of the documentary crew's lost footage, the presentation of which innovated the [[Found footage (pseudo-documentary)|found footage genre]] that was later popularized in American cinema by ''[[The Blair Witch Project]]''. Noted for its [[Realism (arts)|realism]], ''Cannibal Holocaust'' was filmed primarily on location in the Amazon rainforest of [[Colombia]] with [[Indigenous peoples in Colombia|indigenous]] tribes interacting with American and Italian actors.<ref>''Cinema Inferno: Celluloid Explosions from the Cultural Margins''. Weiner, Robert G.; Cline, John (Editors). Scarecrow Press, Inc., 2010. {{ISBN|978-0-8108-7656-9}}.</ref>
''Cannibal Holocaust'' achieved notoriety as its graphic violence aroused a great deal of controversy. After its premiere in Italy, it was ordered to be seized by a local [[Magistrate#Continental Europe and its former colonies|magistrate]], and Deodato was arrested on [[obscenity]] charges. He was later charged with multiple counts of murder due to rumors that claimed several actors were killed on camera. Although Deodato was cleared of these charges, the film was banned in Italy, Australia, and several other countries due to its graphic content, including [[sexual assault]] and genuine [[Cruelty to animals|violence toward animals]]. Although some nations have since revoked the ban, it is still upheld in several countries. In retrospective analyses, the film's violence has been noted as commentary on ethics in journalism, exploitation of developing countries, and the nature of modern society versus uncivilized society, although these interpretations have also been met with criticism.<ref name="David Carter">{{cite web | url=http://www.savagecinema.com/cannibalholocaust.html | title=Savage Cinema | author=Carter, David | publisher=Savage Cinema | accessdate=6 September 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.littlewhitelies.co.uk/features/articles/cannibal-holocaust-16541 |title=Cannibal Holocaust DVD Review |author=Bitel, Anton |publisher=Little White Lies |accessdate=20 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110233913/http://www.littlewhitelies.co.uk/features/articles/cannibal-holocaust-16541 |archivedate=10 November 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Goodall"/>
==Plot== In 1979, an American film crew disappears in the [[Amazon rainforest]] while filming a [[Documentary film|documentary]] about indigenous cannibal tribes. The team consists of Alan Yates, the director; Faye Daniels, his girlfriend and script girl; and two cameramen, Jack Anders and Mark Tomaso. Harold Monroe, an anthropologist at [[New York University]], agrees to lead a rescue team in hopes of finding the missing filmmakers. In anticipation of his arrival, the military conducts a raid on the local Yacumo tribe and takes a young male hostage in order to help negotiate with the natives. Monroe flies in via [[floatplane]] and is introduced to his guides, Chaco and his assistant, Miguel.
After several days of trekking through the jungle, the group encounters the Yacumo tribe. They arrange the release of their hostage in exchange for being taken to the Yacumo village. Once there, the group is initially greeted with hostility and learns that the filmmakers caused great unrest among the people. The next day, Monroe and his guides head deeper into the rainforest to locate two warring cannibal tribes, the [[Ya̧nomamö]] and the [[Sanumá|Shamatari]]. They encounter a group of Shamatari warriors and follow them to a riverbank, where they save a smaller group of Ya̧nomamö from death. The Ya̧nomamö invite Monroe and his team back to their village in gratitude, yet they treat the outsiders with suspicion. To gain their trust, Monroe bathes naked in a river. A group of Ya̧nomamö women emerge from the riverbank to take him to a shrine, where he discovers the skeletal remains of the filmmakers. Angered, he confronts the Ya̧nomamö in the village, during which time he plays a tape recorder. The intrigued natives agree to trade it for the filmmakers' surviving reels of film.
Back in New York, executives of the Pan American Broadcasting System invite Monroe to host a broadcast of the documentary to be made from the recovered film, but Monroe insists on viewing the raw footage before making a decision. The executives first introduce him to Alan's work by showing an excerpt from his previous documentary, ''The Last Road to Hell'', which depicts executions in several war-torn countries. One of the executives tells Monroe that Alan staged such dramatic scenes to get more exciting footage. Monroe then begins to view the recovered footage, which first follows the group's trek through the jungle. After walking for days, their guide, Felipe, is bitten by a venomous snake. The group amputates Felipe's leg with a machete to save his life, but he quickly dies and is left behind. The remaining four locate the Yacumo in a clearing, where Jack shoots one in the leg so they can easily follow him to the village. Once they arrive, the crew forces the tribe into a hut and burns it down in order to stage a massacre for their film. Monroe criticizes the staged scenes and poor treatment of the natives, but his concerns are ignored.
Monroe finishes viewing the footage and expresses his disgust to the station executives regarding their decision to air the documentary. To convince them otherwise, he shows them the remaining, unedited footage that only he has seen. The final two reels begin with the film crew locating and capturing a Ya̧nomamö girl, whom the men take turns raping and filming. They later encounter the same girl impaled on a wooden pole by a riverbank, where they claim that the natives killed her for loss of [[virginity]]. Shortly afterwards, they are attacked by the Ya̧nomamö in revenge for the girl's rape and death. Jack is hit by a spear, and Alan shoots him to prevent his escape so that the team can film how the natives mutilate his corpse. As the three surviving team members try to escape the scene, Faye is captured, and Alan insists that they attempt to rescue her. Mark continues to film as she is stripped naked, gang-raped, beaten, and beheaded. The Ya̧nomamö then pursue and kill the last two team members as the camera drops to the ground in front of Alan's bloody face. Disturbed by what they have seen, the executives order the footage to be destroyed. As Monroe leaves the station, he ponders to himself who the "real cannibals" are.
